description: Humans relate to one another in families, groups, organizations, and communities.
Through traditional and alternative theoretical perspectives on human behavior, students
apply prerequisite and advanced material from biology, sociology, psychology, and social
work to assess situations encountered by social workers. Diverse examples are drawn from
literature -- Love in the Driest Season, The Color of Water, A
Poison Stronger than Love, and from students' autobiographies. Offered annually in
the fall semester. Counts toward management studies concentration. Prerequisites: SOAN 121, PSYCH
241, and BIO 123 or BIO 243; open to non-majors by permission of chair only.
fullname: Human Behavior in the Social Environment
